title: R-Pi case with GPIO access, SD-card tray, LED window

description.text: Building on top of HansH's original Raspberry Pi case, and several derivatives, here is another version with a GPIO access window on top (ideal for attaching jumper wires), a tray to guard the SD card and a small window to see the LEDs.

I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with 1.75mm PLA filament and the build turned out to be fine (but see notes below). ReplicatorG GCode settings used
  • Slicing Profile: Replicator 2 slicing defaults
  • Use Raft/Support: No
  • Use support material: None
  • Use default start/end gcode: Yes
  • Use Print-O-Matic: Yes
    • Settings
    • Object infill (%): 25
    • Layer Height (mm): 0.27
    • Number of shells: 2
    • Feedrate (mm/s): 80
    • Travel Feedrate: 150
    • Print temperature: 240
  • Plastic
    • Filament Diameter (mm): 1.75
  • Extruder
    • Nozzle Diameter (mm): 0.4
    Estimated build time: 41 min Notes With 25% infill, 2 shells and the default medium resolution (.27mm) of Replicator 2, some very small regions in the R-Pi logo on top did not get filled. There might be scope for improvement in slicing algorithms here, but greater infill, a single shell or finer resolution may solve the issue (note that 2 shells actually means 3 because one perimeter is generated regardless). Some filing may be necessary to get a good fit.

This is the first model I designed in Sculptris. It's nothing really great, but I thought I might as well upload it. I will be tinkering with it a bit, trying to get it to stand/print without supports, etc. Feel free to take it and do fun things with the model.   
-UPDATE-  
I've beefed up the legs, tail, and neck a bit more. Added a little additional detail, and have made some slight model adjustments for some variation. I have also changed the base and uploaded additional versions of the model, if you wanted to change it up in Sculptris, or make your own base for it. Should absolutely print with supports.
FOX2 is the latest version. The STL is the ready to print model. The 123dx file is an Autodesk 123D file that has the base and model separate, mostly posted for thoroughness. The OBJ file is the model directly exported from Sculptris.

I would advise against printing small. The tail and legs are a bit fragile, and are prone to breaking during post processing.  
Definitely print with supports.

Update: 2013-02-26:  Lids for the long box are coming this weekend.  Also, individual module boxes, and multi-module tubes.
The plan is to expand this design to accommodate the Tinkerkit shield, and various modules.  My first attempt at housing the modules can be seen in the 120mm parts.  Going forward, I would like to be able to incorporate more modules, without needing a whole lot mor plastic.  If you have any thoughts on how you would like to see the modules integrated, just post in the comments.
Right now, I'm planning on making individual push-together cubes to hold each module, with room inside to run the wires back to the main enclosure.
Optional feet on the lids will also be coming.
Lids for the larger box are in design stage.

0.3mm layers should give the right results.  The enclosure can be scaled up for the MEGA.  I will try and get my hands on a MEGA shield, and post the scaling numbers.
The box and lids are all double-walled, to eliminate warping.  Delamination will be a problem if you are running your hot end too cold, or if your feed rate is to low.  As you can see from the photos, I get pretty good results in ABS.  The pads on the bottom have to be cut away completely, dur to the snug fit on the lids.  There is enough length in the body, that if you want to cut away the last 1mm of layers, you can, and then the fit will be perfect.

title: Magnetic brackets for Flashforge Creator Pro Door

description.text:
I created this and printed for 3 reasons:
1st: Wanted to print something because I can :)
2nd: Was tired of having blue tape hold my door closed
3rd: Please refer back to #1
These brackets are placed anywhere you like around the door of your bot.
All you need is:
A couple of magnets about 3mm in diameter ( You can get them at Home Depot or Harbor Freight) about $2.75 a pack .
A Cabinet door Magnet ( $.78 at HomeDepot) 2 Part Epoxy Resin ( I guess anything that till hold them to the door will work)
These are the places I bought the items. I am sure any home improvement store will carry them as well.

Print out the bracket.
Press in the magnets ( might need to trim up a little)
Measure where you will place the brackets and drill two small wholes so that the bolts and nuts you choose will fit. I used the bolts and nuts that came as extras with my printer. Any bolts and nuts will do.
After drilling and seeing where you want them placed, you can then press the nuts of the bolts into the bracket.
Break apart the casing for the magnets that are for the cabinets you bought at the Hardware store. Inside you will find two pieces of metal and a magnet. ( see pic)
I, grinded the metal plates in order to scuff them up a little. This gets them ready for the epoxy. Place the metal plates on some tape and then apply a small amount of epoxy to them. Let them sit for a minute.
Once sticky, place the metal plates on the brackets, tape side towards the magnet, to align them. Then just close the door and press for a few minutes. You should be able to lift the door and press the tape on the printers door to hold the metal plates in-place until the epoxy cures.

title: Christmas Lego Men of Kansas City

description.text: This year instead of sending Christmas Cards I decided to use my Makerbot to make something unique for my friends. And naturally the project took on a life of its own. The final result was 20 Lego Men at 4x the normal size. Each inscribed with a holiday greeting. Before dispatching them off to the world, I decided it would be nice to take all 20 brothers on a photographic tour of Kansas City. http://picasaweb.google.com/skimbal/LegoMenOfKansasCity?feat=directlink Happy Holidays to all of the Thingiverse Community. -Michael Curry

Print out all the parts in the colors of your choice. Cut the support structure off the hips, and attached the legs to the hips using the leg pins. You will need to glue the leg pins in place. Attache the arms to the Body using the arm pins. You will need to glue the arm pins in place. Press the Body Fringe onto the base of the Body Slide the Face Mask over the Head and use a fine tip permanent marker to trace the face onto the head. Press short bits of 3mm filament into the holes on the hat bottom, the press the hat top down onto it. Now assemble like a standard Lego Man. This thing was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4004
Although all parts except the arms where remodeled from scratch

UPDATE: Devil head and Dragon Skull options added. Instructions

  • Customize and pose until you've got what you want.
  • Generated STL
  • Open STL in repG or similar.
  • Flip model onto back and print with full support.
    • Note:
    Arm Upper Len, Arm Lower len, and forarm to wrist ratio only work with the block arm type. Diddi for the legs. I want more heads, arms, legs, and torsos! This is a call to action, limitations on customizer mean that I can't dynamically load your thing, but I can take an STL, render it a OpenSCAD vector format and add it to this thing. So make an awesome body part, or rip apart a statue. Link what you've got in the comments below and I'll do my bet to get it mashed in fast. Please no more than 7K faces though, I have to convert it to a openscad polyhedron, and due to the way customizer works they need to all be in the same file.

title: Marksman Slingshot handle fishing reel clamp

description.text:
A replacement handle for a cheap Marksman brand slingshot to allow a fishing reel to be attached to the bottom using hose clamps.
I geocache, and sometimes I need to retrieve a container from up high, and this works perfectly to string some paracord over an unused bridge support.
I got this idea years ago from a friend that was into ham radio and used a similar setup to string antennas.
I've also seen similar setups to quickly pull string and wire across suspended ceilings.
Who knows what you sheisters may come up with! Just don't try to fish with it; a weight propelled by a slingshot with a hook attached sounds like a great way to loose an ear/eye/rip open your jugular vein... you get the picture. I'd like to know what you want to use such a device for!

The old handle easily slides out of the slingshot from the top it you spread the yolk just a bit. Print this out, slip it in, the same way the old one came out. Attach your fishing reel with some metal worm drive hose clamps. I used two that could go up to a 2" diameter, and I just cut off the extra band material. You should be able to get use clamps that go up to 1 1/4", the diameter of the mount is is one inch plus a flat spot for the reel mount.
I printed on a stock Printrbot Metal this with the cheapest PLA eBay has to offer with neither brim nor raft; it should be an easy print. I used .2mm layer thickness, 15% infill, .8 thick walls (two layers for my print nozzle. I have it designed so that the frame of the slingshot bears most of the force while shooting and the handle does very little little structurally and merely provides a comfortable grip. No supports should be needed, there's just a small overhang where the bottom of the yolk fits, and my printer bridged this without any drooping at all.

Total project time was less than 1.5 hours including print time. Enjoy!

This is a in progress project that we try to use convention CNC mill/router as a 3D printer. Here, we use Mach3 control software which reads g-code and control the CNC movement. In this setup, we don't need to change the original setup and be able to switch CNC/printing jobs easily. This work is created by Chin-Kai Chang, Rand Voorhies and Lior Elazary at University of Southern California(USC) iLab. http://ilab.usc.edu

• Printer Head mount:
    We choose Makerbot Plastruder MK5(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3290) as our print head. The mount plate and MK5 model can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5221

  • Reprogram extruder controller board:
    In our version of firmware, we implemented a simple serial protocol that takes a serial command to set/read temperature and control DC motor speed.
    For example, send "T220" to set temperature to 220C and send "M255" to set motor pwm to 255. Send "R" to read current temperature and so on.
    In addition, we also use one digital I/O pin(D9) as motor start/stop input which will connect to the computer parallel port used by Mach3. You can find the firmware in download section(iLabProto.pde)

description.header:
3.Create the Mach3 setting file. We create a new Mach3 setting file named "PCNC770M3_Metric_3DP.xml" which is a copy from original CNC setup. Also, we add a new macros folder "PCNC770M3_Metric_3DP" under "C:_Mach3_macros" with all the extruder related M-code(M101,M103,M104,M108,M113,M200,M201,M5) that will generate from skeinforge.
In each M-code .m1s file , it looks like:
description.text:
'M104 Macro Setting the temperature
Dim P
Dim Q
Dim R
Dim Temp as integer

description.header:
P=Param1()
Q=Param2()
R=Param3()
Temp = R
Message("Setting Temp to " & Temp)
Call SendSerial ("T" & Temp & chr(13))
description.text:
This allows Mach3 send serial command and talk to Extruder 4.Setup Mach3 serial and parallel connection to extruder controller board. The idea to have both serial and parallel connection is because we assume there will be some latency of serial command in Mach3. So, we use the serial to set target temperature(M104) and motor speed(M108 because this command does not require very precise timing. Then, we use the parallel port to control the feeder to start/stop(M101/M103) as this command needs to run very fast.
In the serial connection, we need to remove the green pin(RTS#) because when Mach3 try to send a serial command, it will also sent a reset signal which cause extruder MCU to reset and lost all current temp/motor setting. In this way, we can even use a serial terminal to check/set other status when Mach3 is running but not sending any serial command. Here, we hack the coolant pump signal(M8/M9) to replace our Motor start/stop command(M101/M103). We will replace all M101/M103 words to M8/M9 in the g-code later. 5.Generate the g-code from ReplicatorG, as a normal 3D printing procedure. We choose "Cupcake Basic" as our machine driver. 6.Run gcode-clean.pl perl script to create Mach3 usable code.
Even we had implemented all the M-code in Mach3, the g-code still not able to run under Mach3 and requires some adjustment. First, Mach3 doesn't use "S" word in M code because it conflicts with spindle speed code. So, we need to replace all "S" word to "R" word. For example "M108 S220" becomes "M108 R220". Second, skeinforge will generate G1 code with "X Y Z F" in each single line. This will totally mess-up Mach3's movement because CNC mill requires some acceleration and deceleration. The solution is remove all redundant feed rate commands and let Mach3 has enough time to accelerate/decelerate. For example:

Third, replace all M101/M103 motor start/stop commands to M8/M9 as we use coolant pump signal to control the feeder. Notice that before you turn on the motor, you must use "M108 Rxxx" to set motor speed. If you do not set speed first, M8/M9 will not work because motor speed still zero.
  • Now everything is ready to run , all you need to do is hit start button in Mach3 and watch your CNC transform itself to a 3D printer.

description.text:
This is a rocket mount for a Mobius action-cam. This has been designed for an eight inch diameter rocket.
The holes are for 3 mm wood screws.
You can easily modify the mount for any diameter rocket you need by editing my tinkercad model here:
https://tinkercad.com/things/4f7c9ilTxNp
All you have to do is change the diameter of the cylinder "hole" that is cutting through the mount, and realign it to the mount when you are done. I added a second mount, this one with a shrowd that blocks the wind from the upper section of the camera - very useful if you need the aerodynamics, or you want usable sound from the actioncam. The STL is for a 75mm rocket, but I've added a second file in tinkercad that will allow you to use this for any diameter rocket. The copyright on this is unlimited, non-commercial. I know someone who sells a similar (but superior) shrowd here: https://www.etsy.com/listing/177005125/mobius-hd-camera-shroud-for-rockets-3d, and I have no interest in hurting his business.

phone dock
2 piece Z coupler for the QU-BD Two Up. Used to help eliminate Z wobble or Z ribbing. You may want to rotate the file 90 degrees on the Y axis to print cleaner circles so it fits better.

--->Assembly<---
To assemble your just place the large open part around the Z screw loosely oriented so that the flat part of the small opening can go with the flat part of the stepper motor rod then adding the zip ties. I recommend putting the zip ties through the holes to start and tightening them after you have the coupler in place.

--->Explanation<---
To keep it easy and avoid the whole "What size bolt?" snafu I just designed this to used good old zip ties. You'll need to print out both Two Up Z Coupler Flat and Two Up Z Coupler Round for this to work. The flat piece goes with the flat side of the stepper motor and the round with the opposite side. The openings for the zip ties are 4mm wide so they should fit.

If you have any questions feel free to comment and ask. If you have a different size Z screw or stepper motor rod you can do one of two things: let me know in the comments and I'll see if I can't edit the files and upload them, or open the attached Google Sketch file and customize to your hearts content.
hi
An intricate vase created with a spiral growth.  It looks very interesting from the side view or when you rotate - it is mesmerizing.  It has a pine cone like appearance.

This is a complex object and it prints in a strange way because of the way it was made. The fibers get smaller towards the top so it is a good idea to keep the size of the print as large as you can otherwise the ends will get broken off by the print head.
Object was created in Modo.

description.text:
FreeCAD parametric spool holder rollers for a 3D printer. The sizes in the files match a 10 cm long extended roller for the FABtotum, but you can edit the FreeCAD file to make it your wanted size.
With 10 cm you will not be able to fit the side panel of the FABtotum, but you will be able to use most big spools out of the box without needing to un-spool and re-spool to a smaller spool size.
Mines were done with 8 mm inner diameter, with matches the ones comming with the FABtotum, but was very difficult to put the bearings (the ones coming with the FABtotum) in place, as they were too tight. I have modified the file to 8.1 mm, so that you have less amount of trouble. You still might want to tweak the file to a larger value.

comments.text: I remember that someone modified this to mount it on the stock mini rollers. Look in the FABtotum forum in the list of community designs...

remixed_from.author: jprikkel
remixed_from.title: Ultimate 38mm Rotating Spool Holder - MakerBot Replicator 2

description.text:
This is a remix of
"Ultimate 38mm Rotating Spool Holder - MakerBot Replicator 2" by jprikkel. Thanks so much for sharing this design!
I really liked his design and wanted to use it on my M2 so here it is. Pictures show step-by-step instructions and also a parts list using part numbers from McMaster-Carr.
I've included the Cubify Design files in case it needs modification and S3D factory file.
I used ABS 4 layers at .2mm with 70% infill. In the S3D factory file I have it set to "Use random start points for all perimeters. The reason being that if set to the "Optimize" option it would leave a seam on the spool holder which acted as a speed bump and would cause the reel to spin a little quicker than it should. Going to random eliminated that issue.
Please note that the original spool holder file from jprikkel will not work with this mount since I did modify it, so you would need to print both pieces.
The holes for the clips are designed so that the flat side of the clip is placed closest to the spool. There is an indentation inside the holes for the clip to "snap" in.
Also thanks to "markb" from Makergear forum for making me aware of this great spool holder!
VERSION 1.2 - Added grooves to the spool holder. (Note the pictures are from the original version which did not have the groove, the CAD picture does show them.) These groves allow for the use of reel adapters. Included in the files is an adapter with an outside diameter of 52mm. You will need to print two of these, one for each side of the reel (If you have reels with this size opening. These are a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:504298 by trevorjb. Thanks Trevor! I will add more adapters as I run into additional reels with different hole sizes.
One additional note I failed to mention. The spool holder is very tight initially on the bolt. You will need to use a heavy wire brush to ream it out. But this assures a nice smooth fit on the bolt after you do one pass with the wire brush. 03/03/2015: Added the Taulman3D 1lb Spool adapter
Please see the images for assembly instructions and parts list from McMaster-Carr
Fun glass for Funny dress

Print by MakerBot Replicator 2
0.3mm layer high
10% infill
Take around 100mins.
Hope you will like it ;)

As you can see the print quality has gotten better with less bed movement when printing.

Inspired by gzumwalt's popular PLA spring car and Kikkerland's zecar toy, this toy car has a flywheel weighted with 45-50 pennies. You push the car to get the flywheel up to speed, and then the car will keep going straight with enough torque to overcome small obstacles. All parts snap or wedge together, no vitamins except for pennies and rubber bands. I put a lot of time into this, revising every part at least once. I hope you enjoy. See Instructions please. some files revised 11/19/14

GENERAL TIPS...
Watch your fingers! This thing has gears with lots of torque. The roof is not needed, but is recommended if kids will be playing with this. Place 1-2 rubber bands around each back wheel. This is a must. Oil all pivots and shafts, and make sure they spin freely. This will make a big difference. I printed this car once with ABS and again with PLA. The ABS car seemed to work better, possibly because it has a higher melting point, and wont heat up and get gummy on the fast spinning flywheel pivot. Pennies minted before 1982 weigh slightly more than ones minted after (3 grams vs. 2.5 grams), so disperse them equally in the flywheel or only use one or the other. PRINTING TIPS...
None of the prints really require support, slopes over 45 degrees are minimal. When printing the roof use a brim, and keep any heated beds cranked up so it does not tip over. Print all pins and axles with 3 perimeters and a high amount of infill.

title: FlashForge Dreamer Stock Duct Modification
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cooling duct for the right extruder for the FlashForge Dreamer (and other printers using the same left side blower configuration on a dual extruder). Stock duct primarily cools the left extruder and as a result the right extruder can suffer when printing PLA. This modification is designed to direct air to the right extruder and improve printing performance. Not to be used when printing with the left extruder for PLA (swap back to the stock duct).
I originally designed this mod to cool both extruders, however with the stock blower fan, splitting the cooling resulted in a reduction of quality due to a lack of air flow to each extruder.
Recommended to print out of ABS to prevent melting of the duct.
3 Files. RB-C0100-1 Is the complete part. RB-C0101-1 is the main housing only and RB-C0102-1 Is the insert which seats into the blower. I separated these two parts to eliminate the requirement for messy supports. Simply glue together RB-C0101-1 and RB-C0102-1.

title: Bearing - Needle Roller type one piece print (with minimal support to remove)

description.text:
Great 'proof of concept' 3D print... this amazes everyone not familiar to 3D printing!
This needle roller bearing prints as one piece. It has 12 rollers and prints (on a Replicator 2) so the designed in support can be removed in next to no time to leave an easy to spin needle roller bearing.
At the time of uploading I couldn't find anything similar on Thigiverse. The key to it working is the clearances within the design and the designed in support.
TIP: Spray inside from each side with a small squirt of silicone spray to make it spin really well.
Easy print... something to fascinate people with.

On a Replicator 2 print use Raft with 4 shells and 35% fill... don't scale down or the clearances will reduce and it could become a solid block.
When finished remove the support and the designed in support on the underside (that support the rollers) should be quick and easy to remove as they are all attached to a single 'support ring'.

comments.text: Which layer does the supports start forming? It looks as if it starts bridging at 2.5? I was assuming the support started at layer 1. I just started printing it a few minutes ago.
comments.author: Hyprmtr

comments.text: I designed that a couple of years go so had to check back... the designed in support starts from the first layer and is 2.9mm tall. It stops a fraction short of the rollers but close enough for the rollers to stick to the support below as they start to build above. With a good slicing app and a well set up / accurate machine with a filament fan (PLA) this works well. However, not all machines will do it... hopefully this helps.
comments.author: Hyprmtr

comments.text: Thank you for the quick reply.
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: You need to gently break away the minimal designed in support from underneath. With a Replicator 2 it comers away easily and spins almost straight away... not all printers will be as fine or accurate. I have seen some from other brands of printers that literally melt fine things like this into one piece. On the Replicator 2 and 5th Generation Replicators these print well...

This is a 3D printed Speaker that you can print at home.
All you need is some enameled copper wire and a magnet!
Parts have been printed with the LumiPocket 3D printer (http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/lumipocket-affordable-high-quality-3d-printer/)

I designed this lamp for my study (Industrial Design Engineering @ TU Delft). It is a desk lamp consisting of only 3D printed parts and aluminium extrusion (square tube). Due to the easy to modify 3D printed parts and the not hard to come by aluminium extrusion, the lamp can be altered with little effort.

Print all parts at desired resolution (I printed them with 0.1mm layer height and a 0.5mm nozzle). Begin with printing one part to check if the part fits. Scale if necessary.   
Cut the aluminium extrusion to its desired length and optionally apply a surface finish. Keep in mind that paint will add extra thickness to the extrusion. Also drill the holes for the rivets and cables.  
secure all parts with rivets.  
I used a 20 watts halogen lamp for the prototype. DO NOT use such a powerful lamp in such small lampshade. In the new version I'm using LED as light source.

Hello again! I'm coming back with another guerrilla photo equipment, this time it's smart thing for reflecting flashlight upwards. It works similar to external rotary flash. A scene is lit much softer compared to direct flashlight, especially desired when making portraits. Designed in OpenSCAD. It's not typical remix, but I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33823 as a starting point. However, the challenge was to fool Canon's protection against using built-in flash while hot shoe is present. I added a cutout not to affect micro trigger and it solved the problem. I hope some makers find this interesting. Cheers!

This thing contains really small parts and is not easy to print. Travel speed reduction is recommended.
Print all the part (reflector & mount x1, something x2 (one mirrored), arm_a x4). Clean if needed. Assembly it, screw something to mount with M3x5 screws.
Glue reflective/diffusing material to reflectors curved surface. I used gold businesscard cardboard. Printed in transparent plastic works as diffuser.

comments.text: Instead of putting a reflector across the arms you could try putting a piece of white paper to diffuse the flash, might work better. I have a shoemount flash that has a diffuser on it already, works great!

description.text: Copy your own keys by using the customizer and holding your key up to the computer or mobile screen to check.

This is a clamp I invented to hold parts in place on spindles. For example I use 2 of them to keep my filament spool in place. My aim was to create a clamp that could be placed and locked single handed, and provides reasonable holding force. The result seems to do the trick, has no moving parts, and requires no assembly.
The outer ring acts as a spring which when squeezed spreads the inner half rings apart.
PLA works ok but does take on a bit of a set and so relaxes a little over time. ABS seems to work better.
The design is quite simple and most people should be able to recreate and adapt it for their own needs.

  • Pull the casted silicone mold out of the tray.
  • Mix plaster of paris and pour into your silicone mold.
  • Remove the finished plaster ornament.
  • Paint, Decorate, repeat!

description.text: Generate an Aztec Pyramid with ajustable levels

A parametric pulley designed to be clipped on a bearing.
It has flanges to keep the belt in.
It was initially designed to keep off my mendel X-axis belt from the fixed flange.

Parameters are in millimeters except for Flange_Shape which is 1 if you want squared flanges or 2 if you want rounded flanges.
You may have to add a fraction of a millimeter to the Belt_Width to allow some clearance. I have printed it without any noticeable problem. It fits tightly around the bearing and you'll need a hammer to mount it. On a reprap, as the flanges make the pulley a bit larger than the bearing, you'll need to add a washer on each side.

description.text:
This is a project to create a Samsung Galaxy Note 4 model for use in cases holders etc.
At the end of it I want to end up with 3 files. Top and bottom shells for a negative and a phone model with enlarged sections to leave space for access to buttons etc.
It's not an exact copy and needs a fair amount more done to get it working right.
V2.3 Move the power button a few mm and the speaker hole rounded edges and moved down If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w

Its very much still a BETA version and while I think its all more or less right its still not 100% Currently only the botom shell is posted I will post the body once I'm happy its right. Also remember this is a design template to be used for making cases etc not actually a case.

Inspired by the Ultimaker UltiControllerâ€™s streamlined curved wood design, this is the answer to pen chaos on your desk. While an eye candy of rhythmically roasted and bent wood, it cradles your pens for your ultimate convenience.
Made by Alessandro @ Fab Lab Zurich

We used 4 mm thick plywood and laser cut the design straight forward. The puzzle pieces are calculated to hold rather firmly and the bended parts have to stretch around the rounded corners to be in tension and secure the structure. Assembly is a bit tricky, as you have to bend and stretch the flexible parts and at the same time put together the puzzle pieces. The upper and lower notches could be a little deeper to accomodate the upper ring and base better, but it works all in all. 
It can also be used as a vase for flowers without water!

comments.text:
Hi Alessandro
Its a nice pencil holder.
Unfortunately your .dxf file does not work with lasers, which make finer cuts than yours. The .dxf seems to have been generated for a beam width of 0.3mm. However most lasers make thinner cuts. The funlab's laser beam with is below 0.1mm. When I cut your .dxf, the parts dont fit. Usually people also upload the .scad file and not only the .dxf.
Hanspeter

The Z-SupportBracketR and Z-SupportBracketL support the gantry weight and eliminate the axial force on the Z-Motor. Update
The Z-Support Bracket can be also used as a Radial Guide (x and y). I uploaded a ring for this purpose.

The Z-Axis Wobble Absorber http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42260 or a similar solution is recommended in combination with the Z Support Bracket. The Bearing Ring is split into 2 pieces in order to avoid printing with support material.
  • Insert the Bearing into the Ring.
  • Put the Ring with the Bearing into the Z-Support Bracket.
    • BOM for both Support Brackets: 2x Stainless Threaded Rod M8 x 1.25 mm x 320mm long (the original ones are to short and must be replaced).
    2x Bearing 608ZZ or similar: inside dia 8mm, outside dia 22mm.
    2x 8mm Washer.
    2x Hex Nut M8 Nylon Locking.
    2x Spacer i-dia 8mm, o-dia min 10mm, x mm long (the length depends on your Z-Coupling).
    4x (Hex) Screw M5 x 12mm.
    4x 5mm Washer.
    4x Misumi M5 T-Slot Nut.

title: SCE8UU styled housing for Igus RJMP bearings

description.text:
During replacing the Y-carriage of my Prusa i3 "acrylic" i wanted to get rid of the cheap SCE8UU bearings.
As i liked the design of the bearings i decided to make a similar housing for Igus RJMP bearings, you can use this to replace the original ones without drilling new holes ;)
Based on a drawing i found on the web - sorry, no sources known bummer
Included the Inventor drawing

Print it in ABS!
Holes are ment for 4.5mm inner diameter and 4mm screws to turn or push them to have a exact match on your rods.
After that drill the hole for the RJMP bearings to EXACT 16mm
Push the RJMP Bearings into the 16mm holes (1-2kg of force should not exceeded)
Then sand the bottom of the housings on a flat table, having it on a 8mm rod, turn it 180 degrees after a while and sand again - you should have exact leveled bearings after that.
